document.discussion_title: A third of British women admit going out in shoes that stop them walking for TWO DAYS afterwards - Mirror Online
document.topic_text: A third of British women admit going out in shoes that stop them walking for TWO DAYS afterwards 19:13, 25 Apr 2016 19:13, 25 Apr 2016 By Rachel Bishop , Emma Elsworthy A recent survey by Long Tall Sally found that 32% of women are wearing the wrong size shoes, while 75% confessed to owning at least one pair of shoes which are "absolute agony" Shares Click to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started A third of British women have admitted wearing shoes on a night out that they know will stop them walking for TWO DAYS afterwards. The shocking statistics were revealed in a recent survey by Long Tall Sally, which claimed up to 8 million women could be hobbling around days after a night out - all because of their shoes. The company's If the Shoe Fits survey also found that a third of women own a pair of shoes that can only be worn to sit down events and three quarters own at least one pair of shoes which are "absolute agony" to wear. As part of the research, which found that 32% of women are wearing the wrong size shoes, a team took to the streets to test out the findings. Almost all of those quizzed were wearing shoes that were too small for them. Rex Long Tall Sally's If the Shoe Fits survey found that three quarters of women own at least one pair of shoes which are "absolute agony" to wear Head of Garment and Shoe Tech at Long Tall Sally, Lindsey Clark, said: “Even the most beautiful shoes will look unattractive if they’re two sizes too small. Rex According to London Tall Sally's survey of 1,000 women 32% of British women are wearing the wrong size shoes “Stats show that 62% of women haven’t had their feet measured in more than five years, and 45% in more than 10 years. “We urge our customers to head in store and have their feet measured to check they’re wearing the right size shoes. Long Tall Sally On the streets of London, Long Tall Sally quiz passers by about their shoe size “Lots of lifestyle factors can change the shape of a woman’s foot, from pregnancy to ageing to weight loss.” Long Tall Sally Long Tall Sally researchers measured women's feet The poll of 1,000 women also found that more than half say having footwear which “looks good” is most important to them when buying shoes. And most will go on to wear uncomfortable shoes if they match a certain outfit.
